question: [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_primary_oracle_provider()] [Disabled Provider Attack] Can an attacker set a disabled provider as primary, bypassing the enable check if the check only occurs in config module but not validated after setting? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_primary_oracle_provider()] [Provider Swap Race] Between version_verification and set_primary_oracle_provider execution, can an attacker disable the provider being set, causing primary to point to disabled provider? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_primary_oracle_provider()] [Unconfigured Provider] Can an attacker set a provider as primary before creating its oracle_provider_config, causing immediate price query failures? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_primary_oracle_provider()] [Same Provider for Primary and Secondary] Can an attacker set the same provider as both primary and secondary, eliminating fallback redundancy and making price feeds vulnerable to single provider manipulation? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_secondary_oracle_provider()] [Empty Provider Bypass] Can an attacker set secondary to empty provider (oracle_provider::new_empty_provider()) then manipulate primary knowing there's no fallback? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_secondary_oracle_provider()] [Disabled Secondary] Can an attacker set a disabled provider as secondary, and when primary fails, will the system accept disabled secondary prices or properly reject them? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [All Functions] [Version Check Bypass] If config::version_verification() has a vulnerability allowing bypass, can an attacker call any oracle_manage function with outdated oracle_config to exploit old code paths? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [All Functions] [Version Inconsistency] Can an attacker exploit timing between version_migrate() calls and parameter updates to use partially migrated state with mismatched version checks? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Functions: create_price_feed() + set_enable_to_price_feed()] [Initialization Race] Can an attacker front-run create_price_feed by immediately calling set_enable_to_price_feed(false), disabling the feed before legitimate users can query it? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Functions: set_primary_oracle_provider() + disable_pyth_oracle_provider()] [Provider Disable After Set] Can an attacker set Pyth as primary then immediately disable it in next transaction, leaving feed with non-functional primary provider? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Functions: set_maximum_effective_price_to_price_feed() + set_minimum_effective_price_to_price_feed()] [Price Range Collapse] Can an attacker call both functions in rapid succession to create a price range so narrow that legitimate prices are rejected, causing DoS? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Functions: set_price_diff_threshold1_to_price_feed() + set_price_diff_threshold2_to_price_feed()] [Threshold Manipulation Sequence] Can an attacker first set threshold2 very high, then set threshold1 equal to it, creating a single-tier system that bypasses multi-tier protection? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Functions: set_max_timestamp_diff_to_price_feed() + set_historical_price_ttl_to_price_feed()] [Staleness Window Expansion] Can an attacker maximize both values to create extremely long price validity windows, enabling historical price manipulation attacks? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Functions: create_pyth_oracle_provider_config() + create_supra_oracle_provider_config()] [Duplicate Provider Types] Can an attacker create configs for both Pyth and Supra with different pair_ids, then rapidly switch primary provider to cause price volatility? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Multiple Functions] [Invalid Feed ID] Can an attacker pass arbitrary feed_id addresses to parameter update functions, potentially updating wrong feeds or causing out-of-bounds access? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Multiple Functions] [Feed ID Collision] If multiple OracleConfig objects exist, can an attacker use feed_id from config A to update parameters in config B? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Multiple Functions] [Non-existent Feed ID] Do all functions properly validate feed_id existence before updating, or can attacker cause state corruption by updating non-existent feeds? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [All Functions] [Cap Compromise] If OracleAdminCap is transferred to attacker via social engineering or contract vulnerability, can attacker immediately cause catastrophic oracle failure by disabling all feeds and providers? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [All Functions] [Cap Cloning] Is there any way to duplicate or clone OracleAdminCap through Move's object model, allowing multiple parties to have admin control? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [All Functions] [Cap Transfer Race] During OracleAdminCap transfer between addresses, can an attacker intercept and execute malicious oracle configuration changes? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_max_timestamp_diff_to_price_feed()] [Overflow in Timestamp Comparison] If max_timestamp_diff is set to near u64::MAX, can timestamp arithmetic overflow when checking (current_time - oracle_time <= max_timestamp_diff)? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_maximum_allowed_span_percentage_to_price_feed()] [Overflow in Percentage Math] If maximum_allowed_span_percentage is u64::MAX, will (price_change * 10000) calculation overflow and bypass span checks? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: set_maximum_effective_price_to_price_feed()] [u256 Boundary] Can an attacker set maximum_effective_price to u256::MAX - 1 to cause overflow when comparing against actual prices that get incremented? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [Function: create_price_feed()] [Multi-Parameter Overflow] Can an attacker set multiple parameters to maximum values such that combined checks cause overflow (e.g., threshold * span * duration)? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/protocol/oracle/sources/oracle_manage.move] [All Setter Functions] [Event-State Mismatch] If events are emitted before state changes complete, can an attacker exploit the window between event emission and actual update to cause state inconsistency? (Medium)
